I’d only do that if you were having an ArrayList that contained different values like ArrayList(); But it seems like he was using ArrayList, which will return a String value

item.source: [Java] Testing an element in an Array List problem

item.title: [Java] Testing an element in an Array List problem
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You should use equals(), not ==. The operator checks whether the references are the same, but equals() checks the values. When you do something like “Mystring,” that is a constant in the constant pool of the class you are using it in. This means “Mystring” in a different class is an entirely different object. So the == would return false if you checked it to the string constant in a class that didn’t use the same constant when adding it to the list. String has a special method called intern() to store and manipulate constant strings across your entire application, in order to share constant values. Nevertheless, it’s likely more beneficial to simply use equals() instead of the equality operator.

Granted, the above functionality may actually be desired in certain contexts. I am assuming it is unwanted in your application, in which case I am addressing bugs that you may likely face in the continued development of the application.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Testing an element in an Array List problem
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

Kind of off topic but I’m trying to keep in a table like format, but when I get the price I can get values from 2 digits to 4 digits which throws off the end line in the chart I print out like this:

[code]Welcome to the game!

| Option | Description |

| mine | Go to the mine |
| shop | Go to the shop |
| save | Save your game |
| load | Load your game |

Enter your choice:
Contract

| Company: | Decription: |

| Black Fallout Co. | Mine 7 Gold. | 2150 Gold Coins |
| Black Fallout Co. | Mine 3 Diamond. | 950 Gold Coins |
| Stone Heroes Co. | Mine 2 Iron. | 650 Gold Coins |
| Stone Heroes Co. | Mine 6 Coal. | 1850 Gold Coins |

| Option | Description |

| mine | Go to the mine |
| shop | Go to the shop |
| save | Save your game |
| load | Load your game |

Enter your choice:
[/code]

I know there is no top or bottom line but I’m talking about the “|” character at the end. Any ideas on how to fix that?

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Testing an element in an Array List problem
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

How would I cast it? I tried:

[code] if (ores.get(Ore1) == (String) “Stone”) {

		System.out.println("true");
		
	} else {
	

		System.out.println("false");
		
	}[/code]

But it still prints out false. How you I cast it as an element of a string array list?

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Testing an element in an Array List problem
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

Alright this is for the text - based game down below. I’m making a contract system. I have done randomization of company names, randomization of number of ores and types of ores, and now I’m working on the prices. I need a way to check if a random element in and ArrayList equals something. I’ve tried both of the following ways to check it, but neither work.

[code] if (ores.get(Ore1) == “Stone”) {

		System.out.println("true");
		
	} else {
	

		System.out.println("false");
		
	}
	
	if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Stone")) {
	
		System.out.println("true");
		
	} else {
	
		System.out.println("false");
		
	}[/code]

How do I test this or is there not a way? I feel stupid.

Read full topic
